title: How to persuade Garry Kasparov to return to championship chess and beat Magnus Carlsen - Quora

response.answer_text: Chances are, you can’t. Garry has decided to pursue other things. There possibly are people/organisations out there who would bankroll an enormous purse for a Kasparov - Carlsen (non-official title) match but I don’t think GK would be interested, sadly. Honestly though if I was Bill Gates I’d be tempted to put up $100m for a match, I don’t think either of them would turn that down! That being said I will address the other question, whether he could win the title if he did return. I give him a much better chance of doing so than the existing answers do, though agree it’s unlikely. Let’s put it this way, if I was laying his odds on a betting exchange, I would feel very nervous laying 10–1 against him winning the title within 5 years of a return. I believe his current playing strength is at least 2700 Elo, likely higher, and that within a year his playing strength would likely be in the 2775–2825 region. Why am I a bull on Kasparov? He’s the strongest player of all time, in my opinion. This is one of the most debated topics in chess, so I’m not going to rehash arguments here.Despite having played no official competitive games since 2005, he crushed the still top-100 and currently 2688-rated Nigel Short 8.5–1.5 in blitz in 2015, and followed this up by scoring just over 50% in blitz vs Nakamura, Caruana and So in 2016. These are world class performances (admittedly in blitz). If a normal chess player got those results people would probably guess they were rated at least 2750–2800+.Short was asked if Kasparov would still be top 10 if he returned. Short replied “oh, easily, easily” dismissively, as if it was a dumb question to ask. OK Short had just been thrashed by him and is given to hyperbole, but I’d still take his opinion as someone still playing in high level tournaments.Elo inflation is a definite thing. Short was rated 2665 when he played Kasparov for the world title in 1993, and is rated 2688 now. Is Short now really a better player than when he was in 93? Of course not, as he would agree. If Short (aged 52) can still maintain the same rating now that he had at his peak, I fail to see why Kasparov (54) couldn’t get back to 2800+. Ivanchuk (48) also has the same rating he had over 20 years ago.Linked to the above, while some players fall away rapidly with age (Karpov), others remain very strong and fade more slowly (Korchnoi). I’d definitely put Kasparov in the latter camp.It’s not as if his career was faltering results-wise when he retired. He’d just won Linares 2005, with a +4, 8/12 result, and also won his previous tournament, the Russian championship in November 2004, with +5 =5 -0. It’s more that he was playing less than his results were poor. His rating at retirement was 2812, 39 lower than his peak, but in the last 15 years many top players have had similar downswings (eg Magnus is currently 50 below his peak rating)I would give Kasparov a decent chance of qualifying for a title match, because his style is suited to qualifying from tournaments. But for me there are two big barriers. Firstly, would Kasparov really knuckle down to it? and how would he cope psychologically? He wouldn’t have the pressure of being favourite and defending the title, so it could be liberating, but OTOH he wouldn’t have the same aura of invincibility he once had. The defeat to Deep Blue in 1997 really did seem to put a massive dent in his confidence to me, despite his continued tournament successes. How would he manage with grinding through tournaments, initially (at least) probably with mixed results? Even if he is as strong and potentially strong as I still believe, he’s not going to be finishing at the top end of every tournament like he was used to, in fact he may well finish towards the bottom end sometimes. Would his ego cope? Secondly, if he did get a title shot, stylistically facing Magnus would be more like facing Karpov/Kramnik, two players where his actual results never matched the theoretical Elo difference. Kasparov did best against players who would engage him tactically and try to match him blow for blow. Kramnik nullified him superbly in their title match and I think the most likely outcome is Magnus doing the same. But then Magnus has looked less than convincing in his title defences so far, so who knows …

Garry Kasparov retired in 2005 because he knew that the number one spot was slipping out of his hands. He had already lost the world championship title to Kramnik, and it was only a matter of time before he would be passed on the rating list by Anand and Topalov. In 2009, the 46 year old retiree was Magnus Carlsen’s trainer and second. During that time, they played a number of training games, with Magnus winning the majority. Since then, Kasparov hasn’t gotten any younger or less rusty. He’s 54 now, and it’s 12 years since he played a tournament game. I think it’s extremely unlikely that Kasparov would beat Magnus Carlsen and regain the title if he made a comeback to competitive chess. First of all, he would have to qualify for a match, and even that would be very unlikely. I have previously estimated Anand’s chances of winning the title again to be less than 1 %. I think Kasparov’s chances would be less than 0.1 %. More than that, I think it’s impossible to persuade Kasparov to make a comeback. He doesn’t need the money, and he’s not a man who cares for anything other than first place.

It is unlikely that you will be able to persuade him to compete for the championship, but Kasparov did indeed come out of retirement in 2017, returning to professional chess after a 12 year hiatus. But the fact is, this return was not really a commitment to compete at the highest levels, and he now has higher priorities having nothing to do with chess. If you have not noticed he is heavily invested in political topics, both here and in Russia. He is very active in that arena. Just take a look at his Twitter account: Garry Kasparov (@Kasparov63) | Twitter  My Fight for Russia Goes On: Garry Kasparov Declares He also came out with a book (having nothing to do with chess) in 2015:  Winter Is Coming: Why Vladimir Putin and the Enemies of the Free World Must Be Stopped - Kindle edition by Garry Kasparov. Politics & Social Sciences Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com. So it is unlikely that his return to chess will develop into something like vying for the championship. He is very busy with other things, and even with his prodigious talent, it would require an enormous amount of time and effort to even compete at the highest levels, much less the championship. The pool of top players has only gotten stronger since his retirement. And he is 55 years old. His mother, who he was very close to and who accompanied him to matches and tournaments when he was active, just died last month. He has other things on his mind. The king is back: Chess legend Garry Kasparov comes out of retirement Garry Kasparov Returns, Briefly, to Chess

It most likely be to offer Garry a lot of money. Anyway, even if he wanted, it would be extremely difficult for Kasparov to become a real challenger for the title and beating Magnus in just one game isn’t really going to cut it. Frankly speaking, he must be in the 2,600 level now just as Fischer was in his 1992 match. I’d like to see him play Karpov though, as a commemoration of their long world-championship history, using some of those historic openings again.

You cant. Garry would get crushed like a bug. Magnus Carlsen is the greatest chess player of all time and Garry wouldnt even stand a chance in his prime. He has a big ego and he knows he’d get destroyed so he wouldnt even consider this.
Tell him that Putin of Russia will resign…he will immediately agree to everything you say…”the man aint mad about Putin”…never was never will
